# Quick Commands - Delete All Data
## Delete All User Accounts
**PowerShell:** ```powershell Invoke-RestMethod -Uri "http://localhost:3000/users/clear-all" -Method DELETE ```
**Output:** ```json { "message": "Successfully deleted X user(s)", "success": true } ```
---
## List All Users (Before Deleting)
**PowerShell:** ```powershell Invoke-RestMethod -Uri "http://localhost:3000/users/list" -Method GET ```
**Output:** ```json { "count": 5, "users": [ { "id": "...", "email": "user@example.com", ... } ] } ```
---
## Delete All Events and Event Data
Currently, events are tied to users through the database. When you delete all users, the events remain but become orphaned.
**Option 1: Delete via SQL (Recommended)**
Open pgAdmin and run: ```sql DELETE FROM transactions; DELETE FROM buying_stations; DELETE FROM event_members; DELETE FROM events; ```
**Option 2: Delete via psql Command Line** ```bash psql -U postgres -d aha_v2 -c "DELETE FROM transactions; DELETE FROM buying_stations; DELETE FROM event_members; DELETE FROM events;" ```
**Option 3: Recreate Entire Database** ```bash psql -U postgres -c "DROP DATABASE aha_v2; CREATE DATABASE aha_v2;" ``` Then restart your backend server - it will recreate all tables automatically.
---
## Complete Reset (Everything)
**Delete ALL data and start fresh:**
```bash psql -U postgres -c "DROP DATABASE aha_v2; CREATE DATABASE aha_v2;" ```
Then restart backend: ```bash npm run start:dev ```
All tables will be recreated empty.
---
## Notes
⚠️ **Warning:** These actions are permanent and cannot be undone!
**Security:** The `/users/clear-all` endpoint only works in development mode (NODE_ENV=development)
**Backup:** Consider backing up your database first: ```bash pg_dump -U postgres aha_v2 > backup_$(date +%Y%m%d).sql ```

# Email Configuration Notes
## Current Setup
The backend sends verification and password reset emails with links that point to: `http://192.168.1.198:3001`
This is configured in the `.env` file as `APP_URL`.
## Why This Works
- ✅ **Web App**: Works because you can access it at `http://192.168.1.198:3001` from any device on your network - ✅ **Mobile App**: The mobile app will handle the deep linking when you click email links on your phone
## Important Notes
1. **Web App Access**: If you want to access the web app from your phone's browser, use: ``` http://192.168.1.198:3001 ``` Instead of `http://localhost:3001`
2. **Email Links on Mobile**: When you click a verification link in the email on your phone: - It will try to open in the browser first - You can manually trigger the verification in the mobile app by copying the email and token from the URL
## Alternative: Deep Linking (Future Enhancement)
For a better mobile experience, you could configure deep linking so email links automatically open in the mobile app. This requires: 1. Configuring Expo deep links 2. Updating the email service to detect mobile users 3. Sending different links for mobile vs web
For now, the current setup works for both platforms when on the same network.
## If Your IP Changes
Remember to update `APP_URL` in `.env` if your computer's IP address changes: 1. Run `ipconfig` to get your new IP 2. Update `.env`: `APP_URL=http://YOUR_NEW_IP:3001` 3. Restart the backend server
